text.text_translated:
theobromae laanga senaun'lauri hexaconazole na nsdawu 30 j! 

Arphatsara Heedrod: Die-Back of Durian caused by Lasiodiplodia theobromae and Chemical Control. Master of Science (Plant Pathology), Major Field: Plant Pathology, Department of Plant Pathology. 

Thesis Advisor: Associate Professor Ratiya Pongpisutta, Ph.D. Academic Year 2022 

Twenty isolates of Lasiodiplodia fungi isolated from dieback disease of durian in Chanthaburi, Chumphon and Trad provinces were investigated by using morphological characteristics and molecular techniques. Based on colony type, all isolates were separated into 4 groups. Whilst nucleotide sequence analysis of the internal transcribed spacer (ITs), all isolates were identified as Lasiodiplodia theobromae. The optimal conditions for mycelial growth of the fungi were studied. It was found that the mycelia of L. theobromae grew very well at $2 5 { - } 3 5 \ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ,$ $\mathrm { p H } ~ 7 â€“ 8$ and on the medium containing glucose, sucrose, $\mathrm { N H 4 S O _ { 4 } }$ and $\mathrm { N H } 4 \mathrm { S O } _ { 3 }$ . Four representative isolates of each group were inspected on pathogenicity test on durian seedlings and found the disease symptom showing on inoculated durian seedlings. Cross inoculation in six other seedling plants as coffee, cocoa, pepper, mango, papaya and rubber was investigated. The four isolates could infect onto the seedlings of 6 plant varieties also. Moreover, the fungal isolate DCHA221 represented the highest aggressiveness. In vivo test of fungicide efficiency was inspected and found that carbendazim, hexaconazole, procymidone, propiconazole and quintozene (control) were the most effective. Then, two fungicides as carbendazim and hexaconazole were selected to apply on durian seedlings in the greenhouse. Additionally, quintozene was used as comparison treatment. The results showed that carbendazim and quintozene applications with recommended rates were the most effective, followed by hexaconazole in controlling L. theobromae after 30 days spraying.

The distribution of a certain proportion across Thailand's provinces shows the highest concentrations in the eastern and southern regions. Chanthaburi and Chumphon exhibit the highest proportions, indicated by the darkest shading, representing values between 30% and 40%. Other provinces with significant proportions include Trat and Yala. A moderate proportion, around 10% to 20%, is observed in several provinces, such as Rayong, Surat Thani, Nakhon Si Thammarat, and Songkhla in the south, as well as Chonburi, Prachinburi, and Nakhon Ratchasima. The lowest proportions, generally below 10%, are widespread across the northern and central regions, including provinces like Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Sukhothai, Kanchanaburi, and Phetchaburi.

This table, attributed to Febbiyanti et al. (2019), shows the progression of symptoms over time following inoculation. The first column lists the kind of symptom, while the second column provides the time range in 'Days after inoculation' for its appearance. The symptoms develop in a clear sequence, starting with 'Spot' appearing between 10-13 days. This is followed by 'Scab' from 11-20 days and 'Skin and leave drying' from 17-25 days. More severe symptoms emerge later, with 'Decayed xylem tissue' appearing from 22-28 days and finally 'Branch dry and die' from 25-35 days. The main takeaway is that the symptoms appear in a chronological order of increasing severity over a period of up to 35 days.

The microscopic anatomy of a fungus is detailed in several views. Two large, globose fruiting bodies, labeled (a) and (b), are shown in cross-section, revealing an outer wall enclosing numerous internal spores, with a scale of 500 micrometers. Associated with these are smaller, bacilliform structures. Labeled (c) are the conidiogenous structures at a 10-micrometer scale, depicting conidiophores and sterile setae emerging from a cellular base, with some conidiophores bearing terminal, oval, stippled conidia. A collection of mature spores is shown under label (d), featuring both dark, muriform ascospores with distinctive striations and lighter, oval, stippled spores.

The table outlines the components and quantities for a single laboratory reaction. The rows list eight different elements, and the columns detail their concentrations and volumes. The first column identifies each element and its stock concentration (e.g., 'Taq buffer 10X'). The second column, which has a complex header 'Concentration Final concentration Volume/1 reaction (l)', appears to list two separate values for most elements: the final concentration and the volume per reaction. For instance, the DNA template is used at a final concentration of 20 ng with a volume of 2.0. Sterile distilled water is the component with the largest volume, listed as 14.4. The volumes for Taq buffer and MgC12+ are both 2.4, while dNTPs, forward primer, and reverse primer each have a volume of 1.2. Taq polymerase has the lowest volume at 0.2. The unit for volume is stated as '(l)', but this may be a typo for a smaller unit. Overall, the table provides a recipe detailing the final concentrations and required volumes for eight components in a single reaction.

1943 

This table presents a list of biological isolates recorded in the GenBank database. Each row represents a unique isolate, while the columns specify the isolate's name, the host species from which it was collected, the country of origin, and its corresponding GenBank accession number. The isolates were sourced from a variety of plant hosts across several countries. For example, isolates from 'Vitis vinifera' and 'Carica papaya' were all collected in Mexico. Isolates from 'Mangifera indica' were found in Mexico, Egypt, and Peru, while those from 'Persea americana' were found in China and Peru. Other hosts are linked to single countries in this dataset, such as 'Cocos nucifera' from Brazil, 'Dimocarpus longan' from Puerto Rico, and 'Fragaria ananassa Duchesne' from The United States. Overall, the table serves as a reference linking specific isolates to their host plants, geographical origins, and unique database identifiers.

The table lists the concentrations or quantities of seven different elements for a chemical or biological mixture. Each row identifies a specific component and its corresponding value. The components are DNA template (1.0), sterile distilled water (15.075), Dream Tap buffer (2.5), MgCl2+ (0.25), dNTPs (5), primer (1.2), and Dream Tap polymerase (0.175). Of these, sterile distilled water has the highest value at 15.075, while Dream Tap polymerase has the lowest at 0.175. The table concludes with a total of 25, which is the approximate sum of all the individual element values. In summary, the table provides a recipe for a 25-unit mixture, detailing the specific amount of each ingredient.

This table lists six different primers, providing their corresponding DNA sequences and annealing temperatures in degrees Celsius. Each row represents a unique primer, identified by name in the first column, with its sequence (from 5' to 3') in the second column and its annealing temperature in the third. The annealing temperatures range from a low of 53Â°C for primer (AG8)C to a high of 58Â°C for primer (CAG)5. Three primers, (GACA)4, UBC809, and UBC891, share an annealing temperature of 54Â°C. A footnote clarifies that in the sequence for UBC891, the symbol 'H' can be A, C, or T, and 'V' can be A, C, or G. Overall, the table provides the specific sequences and required annealing temperatures for a set of six primers.

This table provides a morphological analysis of immature and mature conidia from twenty different isolates. Each row corresponds to a specific isolate, identified by codes such as DCHA106 and DTRA12. The columns are grouped into characteristics for 'Immature conidia' and 'Mature conidia', specifically their sizes in '(m)' and shapes. A consistent pattern emerges from the data: all immature conidia are described as 'oval' in shape, while all mature conidia are described as 'oval, ellipsoid'. In terms of size, the first measurement range for immature conidia is consistently larger than the corresponding range for mature conidia. For instance, isolate DCHU1804 has an immature size range of 26.8-29.5, which decreases to 23.8-25.0 for its mature conidia. The second size measurement shows more varied changes between the two stages. In summary, the data consistently shows that as the conidia mature, their shape diversifies and their primary size dimension decreases.

This table provides a morphological analysis of immature and mature conidia from twenty different isolates. Each row corresponds to a specific isolate, identified by codes such as DCHA106 and DTRA12. The columns are grouped into characteristics for 'Immature conidia' and 'Mature conidia', specifically their sizes in '(m)' and shapes. A consistent pattern emerges from the data: all immature conidia are described as 'oval' in shape, while all mature conidia are described as 'oval, ellipsoid'. In terms of size, the first measurement range for immature conidia is consistently larger than the corresponding range for mature conidia. For instance, isolate DCHU1804 has an immature size range of 26.8-29.5, which decreases to 23.8-25.0 for its mature conidia. The second size measurement shows more varied changes between the two stages. In summary, the data consistently shows that as the conidia mature, their shape diversifies and their primary size dimension decreases.

The phylogenetic analysis shows that Lasiodiplodia corticola is the most basal species. The remaining species form a large clade, which separates into two primary subclades. The first subclade, with a support value of 74, further divides into a group containing Lasiodiplodia theobromae and L. parva, and another group containing L. pseudotheobromae and L. gonubiensis. The second primary subclade, with a support value of 85, also branches into two. One branch groups L. venezuelensis and L. rubropurpurea. The other branch contains a pairing of L. mutila and L. cupressi, which is sister to a clade grouping L. seriata, L. sapinea, and L. scrobiculata.

The first subclade, with a support value of 74, further divides into a group containing Lasiodiplodia theobromae and L. parva, and another group containing L. pseudotheobromae and L. gonubiensis. The second primary subclade, with a support value of 85, also branches into two. One branch groups L. venezuelensis and L. rubropurpurea. The other branch contains a pairing of L. mutila and L. cupressi, which is sister to a clade grouping L. seriata, L. sapinea, and L. scrobiculata.

This table displays a genetic analysis of what appears to be *Lasiodiplodia theobromae*, showing nucleotide differences in samples from various plant hosts and countries. The rows correspond to specific samples, identified by host species and country of origin. The columns detail nucleotide variations at specific positions (e.g., 23, 25, 73, 78) and a final column showing the total percentage of difference over a 510 base pair region. The isolate from *Vitis vinifera* in Mexico exhibits the highest variation, with a 0.78% difference. This is followed by the sample from *Mangifera indica* in Mexico at 0.58%. Two other samples, from *Dimocarpus longan* in Puerto Rico and *Fragaria x ananassa* in the US, both show a 0.39% difference. A large number of samples from various hosts in Egypt, Peru, Brazil, China, and Thailand show no variation, with a 0.00% difference. The main takeaway is that most isolates showed no genetic variation in the analyzed region, but a few, primarily from hosts in Mexico, the US, and Puerto Rico, displayed distinct nucleotide differences.

The isolate from *Vitis vinifera* in Mexico exhibits the highest variation, with a 0.78% difference. This is followed by the sample from *Mangifera indica* in Mexico at 0.58%. Two other samples, from *Dimocarpus longan* in Puerto Rico and *Fragaria x ananassa* in the US, both show a 0.39% difference. A large number of samples from various hosts in Egypt, Peru, Brazil, China, and Thailand show no variation, with a 0.00% difference. The main takeaway is that most isolates showed no genetic variation in the analyzed region, but a few, primarily from hosts in Mexico, the US, and Puerto Rico, displayed distinct nucleotide differences.

This table provides a catalog of biological isolates, detailing their host plant species, country of origin, and their corresponding GenBank accession numbers for genetic sequencing data. Each row represents a specific isolate, with columns providing its name, host, location, and database identifier. The isolates originate from a wide variety of hosts, including Vitis vinifera (grape) from Mexico, Mangifera indica (mango) from Mexico, Egypt, and Peru, and Cocos nucifera (coconut) exclusively from Brazil. Other hosts listed are Persea americana (avocado) from China and Peru, Carica papaya from Mexico, Dimocarpus longan from Puerto Rico, Passiflora laurifolia from China, and Fragaria ananassa Duchesne (strawberry) from The United States. Most entries are complete, though a few have missing data, such as an isolate from Puerto Rico with no listed name or host, and one Passiflora laurifolia isolate (PaS-1) without a GenBank number. Overall, the table serves as a reference linking specific isolates from diverse global sources and hosts to their genetic data.

The phylogenetic analysis reveals several distinct clades among the sampled species. A large, singular clade is composed entirely of various Durio zibethinus accessions. Sister to this group is a clade, supported by a bootstrap value of 86, which includes Cocos nucifera, Passiflora edulis, and Carica papaya. Another major branch, with a bootstrap value of 65, groups together Persea americana, a separate cluster of Cocos nucifera, and one group of Mangifera indica. The lower portion of the tree contains a clade for Dimocarpus longan, which is sister to a group that includes Fragaria x ananassa (bootstrap 86) and another clade with a bootstrap value of 71. This final clade splits into two subclades: one for a second group of Mangifera indica (with an internal bootstrap of 81) and another, strongly supported clade (bootstrap 97) for Vitis vinifera.

The table presents a summary of genetic diversity metrics across six different populations or loci, labeled as Pop. The rows correspond to each population and a final 'Mean' row, while the columns detail various genetic statistics: 'n', number of different alleles ('Na''), number of effective alleles ('Ne' 1'), diversity ('h''), and the percentage of polymorphic loci. The formatting for the 'Ne' 1', 'h'', and 'uh' Polymorphic loci' columns is ambiguous, as some cells contain multiple numbers without clear distinction. Based on the primary values, the '(AG8)C' population exhibits the highest genetic diversity, with the highest values across all metrics: 'n' of 12, 'Na'' of 2.00, 'Ne' 1' of 1.55, 'h'' of 0.32, and 100% polymorphic loci. In contrast, the '(GTG)5' population shows the lowest diversity, with the minimum values in most categories, including an 'n' of 5, 'Na'' of 0.83, and 41.67% polymorphic loci. The 'Mean' row provides averages across all populations, such as 1.52 for 'Na'' and 76.39% for polymorphic loci. Overall, the data highlights significant variation in genetic diversity among the analyzed populations, with '(AG8)C' being the most diverse and '(GTG)5' being the least.

One major cluster, formed at a coefficient of approximately 0.35, is composed of two primary subgroups. The first subgroup contains a tight pairing of DCHU106 and DCHU601, which is linked to a larger collection that includes DCHA1105 and a cluster of DCHA416, DCHA106, DCHA901, DCHA221, DCHA1806, and DCHA1805. A separate, distinct cluster at the bottom of the dendrogram consists of two pairs: DTRA706 with DTRA203, and DCHU1203 with DCHA1703.

This table presents the growth rate of diameter, measured in cm/day on day 2, for four groups of colony types under three different chemical treatments. The rows list the treatments (NH,SO4, NH,SO,, NH4C1) and statistical metrics, while the columns are organized by colony groups: G1, G2, G3, and G4, with G2 and G3 sharing a column. The highest growth rate observed is 2.82 cm/day for group G2 under the 'NH,SO,' treatment, while the lowest is 1.98 cm/day for group G1 under the same treatment. According to the footnote, values in the same column followed by the same letter are not significantly different. The table also provides statistical validation, including the Coefficient of Variation (C.V. %), F-test results which are highly significant ('***'), and the Least Significant Difference (LSD) for each group. Overall, the data indicates that both the chemical treatment and the colony group significantly affect the diameter growth rate.

A series of four charts display the growth rate of diameter for four different strains: DCHA221, DTRA706, DCHA106, and DCHU204, under varying conditions. The first chart shows that the optimal temperature for growth is 25Â°C, with a sharp decline at 30Â°C and no growth at 40Â°C. The second chart indicates that the growth rate is lowest at pH 5, increases to a peak at pH 7, and remains high at pH 8 and pH 9. The third chart compares carbon sources, revealing that glucose and sucrose support similar, high levels of growth, while cellulose results in lower growth. The fourth chart shows that three different nitrogen sourcesâ€”NH4SO4, NH4SO3, and NH4Clâ€”all support similarly high growth rates.

This table displays the average lesion length in centimeters (cm) on various plants after exposure to different isolates, compared to a control group. The rows list a control and four isolate groups (G1, G2, G3, G4), while the columns represent the different plants tested: Durian, Coffee, Cocoa, Black pepper, Mango, Papaya, and Rubber. The control group shows no lesions (0.0 cm) across all plants. Isolate G1 (DCHA221) consistently caused the largest lesions, with the maximum recorded on Mango at 9.9 cm. Conversely, isolate G2 (DTRA706) generally resulted in the smallest lesions, with the lowest being 0.9 cm on Papaya. Mango and Coffee plants appear to be the most susceptible to the isolates, while Papaya and Rubber show smaller lesion lengths. The table also includes statistical measures like the Coefficient of Variation (C.V. %), highly significant F-test results, and Least Significant Difference (LSD) values for each plant. Overall, the data indicates that isolate G1 is the most pathogenic, and Mango is one of the most susceptible plants.

A series of images, labeled A through I, documents the condition of plant twigs. Panels A through E show the external appearance of twigs, with what appears to be a progression of dieback from the tip. Panel F provides a close-up comparison of a healthier-looking twig on the left and a darker, more affected twig on the right. Panels G and H show longitudinal sections, with G revealing healthy green internal tissue and H showing browned, necrotic tissue. Panel I is a microscopic view of the twig surface, where a red arrow points to small, dark, embedded structures, possibly fungal bodies.

A series of images displays symptoms of disease on plant stems. Panels A through E show the external progression of necrosis on cut stems. Panel A depicts a healthy green stem. Panel B shows a stem that is entirely blackened. Panel C shows discoloration spreading from the top, while panel D illustrates browning that extends down past the branching node. Panel E shows a sharp demarcation between a black upper portion and a green lower portion of the stem. Panels F and G compare longitudinal sections, with F showing healthy, light-colored internal tissue and G showing diseased, browned tissue. Panel H provides a microscopic view of a stem's surface, with a red arrow indicating small, dark, circular structures, likely fungal fruiting bodies.

The progression of symptoms on plant stems is shown across eight panels. Panels A through E display various stages of tip dieback. Forked stems in panels A, B, and C show an increasing area of black discoloration spreading downwards from the cut tip. Unbranched stems in panels D and E also exhibit this tip necrosis. Internal conditions are revealed in panels F and G, which show longitudinally sectioned stems; panel F displays minor internal discoloration, while panel G shows extensive internal browning. Panel H provides a close-up view of a stem's surface, which is covered in small, black, raised structures, with a red arrow pointing to one of them.

Panel B depicts a cutting where the tip has turned dark and necrotic, though new leaves sprout from below. Panels C, D, and E illustrate successful and progressively more developed regrowth, with healthy new leaves and shoots sprouting from the side of the stem just below the cut surface. Finally, panel F shows a longer stem segment with multiple nodes, from which a well-developed leafy shoot has grown at the top.

Lasiodiplodia theobromae

text.text_translated:
Lasiodiplodia theobromae

L. theobromae is a fungal pathogen causing fruit rot in many economic fruit crops. L. theobromae can infect longan, rambutan, lychee, and longkong (Prakong et al., 2004; Niphon et al., 2012; Aphichat, 2015; Phakamat et al., 2017).

In tests of chemical efficacy at 3 concentrations (125, 250, and 500 ppm), it was found that at 125 ppm, carbendazim, propiconazole, hexaconazole, and procymidone were effective. Difenoconazole and pyraclostrobin were effective at inhibiting growth at concentrations of 125 and 187.5 ppm. Iprovalicarb, propineb, and copper hydroxide had an efficacy of less than 50 percent, while metalaxyl was completely ineffective against 4 isolates of L. theobromae (out of 9 isolates from 10 longan orchards) (Table 16 and Figures 19-22).

For isolate DCHA221 at 100 ppm, carbendazim, hexaconazole, and propiconazole were 100% effective. Procymidone was 89.9% effective and quintozene was 84.8% effective. Pyraclostrobin and difenoconazole had efficacies of 65.8-81.3% and 57.7-83.0%, respectively. Iprovalicarb, propineb, and copper hydroxide at 500 ppm had less than 20% efficacy, while metalaxyl was completely ineffective against isolate DCHA221 (Table 16 and Figure 19).

For isolate DTRA706, carbendazim, hexaconazole, propiconazole, and quintozene (in the lab) were 100% effective at 3 concentrations. Procymidone was 82.1%, 100%, and 100% effective. Difenoconazole was 72%, 81.4%, and 100% effective. Pyraclostrobin was 53%, 82.1%, and 100% effective. Copper hydroxide at 500 ppm had less than 30% efficacy, while metalaxyl, iprovalicarb, and propineb were completely ineffective against isolate DTRA706 (Table 16 and Figure 20).

This table displays the percentage of mycelial growth inhibition for four fungal groups (G1, G2, G3, G4) when treated with various fungicides at different concentrations. The rows list the fungicides and their recommended rates, while the columns show the inhibition percentages for each fungal group at concentrations of 125, 250, and 500 ppm. The table's formatting is challenging to read, as concentrations and results are sometimes combined within single cells. text.text_translated:
This table displays the percentage of mycelial growth inhibition caused by two fungicides, pyraclostrobin and quintozene (as a control), on four different groups of colony types (G1, G2, G3, G4). The rows correspond to the fungicides and statistical measures, while the columns show the test concentrations in parts per million (ppm) and the resulting inhibition percentages. For pyraclostrobin, increasing the concentration from 125 ppm to 250 ppm generally increased growth inhibition across all groups. At 125 ppm, inhibition ranged from 25.7% to 65.8%, while at 250 ppm, it ranged from 74.4% to 88.3%. The data for the control fungicide, quintozene, is poorly structured, but it appears to show very high inhibition, frequently reaching 100%, especially in groups G3 and G4. The main takeaway is that quintozene generally showed higher efficacy than pyraclostrobin, and pyraclostrobin's effectiveness increased with concentration, though the table's formatting for the control data is ambiguous.

1943 

The effects of ten different treatments, labeled A through J, on microbial growth are compared across four concentration levels: a control, 125 ppm, 250 ppm, and 500 ppm. The control samples for all ten treatments show full, dense, greenish growth across the petri dishes. At a concentration of 125 ppm, varied levels of growth inhibition are observed. Treatment A results in almost complete inhibition, whereas treatments B, E, and F still show substantial dark-colored growth. Treatments C, D, G, H, I, and J display small, localized colonies. Increasing the concentration to 250 ppm and 500 ppm generally enhances the inhibitory effect, with treatment A showing complete inhibition at higher concentrations, and the colonies in treatments C, I, and J becoming progressively smaller. In contrast, treatments like B and F maintain significant growth even at the highest concentration of 500 ppm.

The results of a microbial growth experiment are shown for ten different samples, labeled A through J, under four conditions. In the 'Control' row, all samples exhibit extensive, greenish fungal growth covering the entire petri dish. At concentrations of 125 ppm, 250 ppm, and 500 ppm of a test substance, varying levels of growth inhibition are observed. Samples A, C, G, and H show almost complete inhibition at all concentrations. Sample B displays significant dark-colored growth, which is progressively inhibited as the concentration increases. Samples E, F, and I show unique, irregular growth patterns under treatment. A reddish coloration in the culture medium is also visible in several treated samples, particularly D, G, H, and J.

A comparative experiment assesses fungal growth across ten samples, labeled A through J, under a control condition and three different treatment concentrations: 125 ppm, 250 ppm, and 500 ppm. The control group consistently shows extensive, uniform greenish-grey fungal growth across all ten petri dishes. At the 125 ppm concentration, varied responses are observed: samples A, D, G, H, and J exhibit significant growth inhibition, whereas samples B and E show more widespread dark fungal growth, and C and I display distinct compact colonies. With an increased concentration to 250 ppm, the inhibitory effect is generally stronger across all samples. At the highest concentration of 500 ppm, there is a pronounced and uniform inhibition of fungal growth in all ten samples, with growth being limited to very small central colonies.

A5nn 17 sgannwunsanunniaesn3 kia lunnsaugug051 Lasiodiplodia theobromae leTgan DCHA221 lusg 1sasu nanisaw! 

The table presents the results of an experiment evaluating various treatments on disease control, measuring both disease incidence as a percentage and disease severity in centimeters. Each row represents a different treatment group: a negative control, a positive control, carbendazim (500 ppm), hexaconazole (75 ppm), and quintozene (240 ppm). The positive control group showed the highest disease impact with 80% incidence and 3.8 cm severity. The negative control, as expected, had zero disease. Among the chemical treatments, carbendazim and quintozene were the most effective, both reducing disease incidence to 30% and severity to 1.0 cm and 1.1 cm, respectively. Hexaconazole was less effective, resulting in 50% incidence and 2.0 cm severity. A footnote indicates that severity values followed by the same letter are not significantly different, confirming that the effects of carbendazim and quintozene were statistically similar. The table also includes a Coefficient of Variation (C.V.) of 20.3% and a Least Significant Difference (LSD) of 0.4. Overall, the data indicates that carbendazim and quintozene provided the most significant reduction in disease incidence and severity.

A comparison of a plant stem under five different conditions is shown in panels labeled A through E. Panel A displays a healthy-looking brown stem with a Y-shaped fork. Panel B shows a stem with a vertical lesion filled with a white substance. Panel C presents a stem with a long, dark vertical line. Panel D features a stem with a glossy or wet appearance. Panel E shows another healthy-looking stem with a Y-shaped fork, similar to the one in panel A.
